text: Water Snake Plants every 2-3 weeks. Allow soil to dry completely between waterings. Overwatering is the most common cause of death.
Snake Plants thrive in low to bright indirect light. They can tolerate low light conditions but grow faster with more light.
Yellow leaves on Snake Plants usually indicate overwatering. Check soil moisture and reduce watering frequency.
Water Fiddle Leaf Figs when the top 2 inches of soil are dry. Water thoroughly until water drains from the bottom.
Fiddle Leaf Figs need bright, indirect light. Place near a bright window but avoid direct sunlight which can burn leaves.
Brown spots on Fiddle Leaf Fig leaves often indicate inconsistent watering. Maintain a regular watering schedule.
Dropping leaves on Fiddle Leaf Figs can be caused by overwatering, underwatering, or sudden environmental changes.
Water Monsteras when the top inch of soil is dry. They prefer consistently moist but not soggy soil.
Monsteras need bright, indirect light to develop their characteristic split leaves. Too little light results in solid leaves.
Monsteras are climbing plants that benefit from moss poles or trellises for support as they grow taller.
Water Pothos when the top inch of soil feels dry. They're forgiving plants that can tolerate some neglect.
Pothos can grow in low to bright indirect light. Variegated varieties need more light to maintain their patterns.
Pothos are easy to propagate. Cut a stem with 4-6 leaves and place in water or moist soil to root.
Water succulents deeply but infrequently. Allow soil to dry completely between waterings to prevent root rot.
Succulents need bright, direct light for at least 6 hours daily. Insufficient light causes stretching and weak growth.
Use well-draining cactus or succulent soil mix. Regular potting soil retains too much moisture for succulents.
Peace Lilies prefer consistently moist soil. Water when the top inch feels dry and mist leaves regularly.
Peace Lilies thrive in low to medium indirect light. Avoid direct sunlight which can scorch their leaves.
Drooping Peace Lily leaves usually indicate the plant needs water. They're excellent at communicating their needs.
Water Spider Plants when the top inch of soil is dry. They prefer slightly moist soil but can tolerate some drying.
Spider Plants thrive in bright, indirect light but can tolerate lower light conditions. Avoid direct sun.
Spider Plants produce baby plants (spiderettes) that can be easily propagated by placing in water or soil.
Water Aloe Vera deeply but infrequently. Allow soil to dry completely between waterings to prevent root rot.
Aloe Vera needs bright, direct light for at least 6 hours daily. Insufficient light causes weak, stretched growth.
Brown tips on Aloe Vera leaves often indicate overwatering or mineral buildup in soil. Flush soil occasionally.
Water Rubber Plants when the top 2 inches of soil are dry. They prefer slightly moist but well-draining soil.
Rubber Plants need bright, indirect light. Too little light causes leggy growth and leaf drop.
Yellow leaves on Rubber Plants often indicate overwatering. Check soil moisture and drainage.
Water ZZ Plants every 2-3 weeks. They store water in their rhizomes and prefer to dry out between waterings.
ZZ Plants can tolerate low light conditions but grow best in bright, indirect light. Avoid direct sunlight.
Fertilize houseplants during growing season (spring and summer) with balanced liquid fertilizer diluted to half strength.
Repot plants when roots are visible at drainage holes or plant becomes root-bound. Use pot one size larger.
Most houseplants prefer 40-60% humidity. Use humidifiers, pebble trays, or misting to increase humidity.
Most houseplants prefer temperatures between 65-75°F (18-24°C). Avoid drafts and sudden temperature changes.
Brown leaf tips often indicate low humidity, over-fertilization, or water quality issues. Check all care factors.
Water Snake Plants every 2-3 weeks during growing season, less in winter. Allow soil to dry completely between waterings. Overwatering causes root rot.
Snake Plants thrive in low to bright indirect light. They can survive in very low light but grow faster with more light. Avoid direct sun.
Yellow leaves indicate overwatering. Brown tips suggest underwatering. Drooping leaves mean too much water. Check soil moisture.
Water Fiddle Leaf Figs when top 2 inches of soil are dry. Water thoroughly until it drains from bottom. Inconsistent watering causes leaf drop.
Fiddle Leaf Figs need bright, indirect light. Place near east or west-facing window. Rotate plant weekly for even growth.
Brown spots on leaves indicate inconsistent watering. Dropping leaves mean overwatering, underwatering, or sudden changes. Maintain consistent care.
Water Monstera when top inch of soil is dry. Water thoroughly and allow excess to drain. Overwatering causes yellow leaves.
Monsteras prefer bright, indirect light. Too much direct sun burns leaves. Too little light reduces leaf fenestrations.
Monsteras love high humidity (60-80%). Use humidifier, pebble tray, or mist regularly. Low humidity causes brown leaf edges.
Water Pothos when soil feels dry to touch. These plants are drought-tolerant and prefer to dry out between waterings.
Pothos adapts to various light conditions from low to bright indirect light. Variegated varieties need more light to maintain patterns.
Pothos propagates easily in water or soil. Cut below a node and place in water. Roots develop in 1-2 weeks.
Water succulents deeply but infrequently. Soak soil completely, then let dry out completely. Water every 1-2 weeks in growing season.
Succulents need bright, direct light for 6+ hours daily. Insufficient light causes stretching and loss of color.
Use well-draining soil mix for succulents. Add perlite or sand to regular potting soil. Ensure pots have drainage holes.
Water Peace Lily when soil surface feels dry. These plants droop dramatically when thirsty, making watering needs obvious.
Peace Lilies prefer low to medium indirect light. Too much direct sun burns leaves. They can survive in low light but may not flower.
Brown leaf tips indicate overwatering or water quality issues. Yellow leaves mean overwatering. Drooping means underwatering.
